results.headline: Doting Father, Loving Husband, Nazi Leader
results.summary_short: “The Decent One” uses the personal letters and photos of Heinrich Himmler to create a documentary illustrating his rise to power in the Third Reich.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Der Anständige

results.headline: How a Meteor Rose From a Hotbed of Hip-Hop
results.summary_short: “Nas: Time Is Illmatic” revisits a rapper’s roots in a Queens housing project and credits his parents for striving to nurture his ambition.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nas: Time is Illmatic

results.headline: Games People Play, Both Online and Off
results.summary_short: “Men, Women & Children” is Jason Reitman’s multistory film about middle-class families with teenagers, Internet connections and digital issues.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Men, Women & Children

results.headline: A Cause Unites Unlikely Partners in South Wales
results.summary_short: “Pride” brings to film the true 1980s story of when gay activists chose to support union miners in Thatcher’s Britain.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pride

results.headline: Masters of Charity (and Deception)
results.summary_short: “Believe Me,” directed by Will Bakke, wades into an ethical conundrum involving faith-based fund-raising.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Believe Me

results.headline: Sex and the Snow
results.summary_short: In “Two Night Stand,” a couple react to being snowed in after a one-night stand.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Two Night Stand

results.headline: A Tour Guide Goes Above and Beyond
results.summary_short: “The Two Faces of January” is based on a 1964 Patricia Highsmith novel about two affluent American tourists vacationing in Europe.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Two Faces of January

results.headline: A Musician Pastures His Flock Among the Lilies
results.summary_short: In “The Song,” a country music singer faces temptations on the road and chooses the straight and narrow only after having indulged in pleasures and debaucheries.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Song

results.headline: For the Aged, a Shrinking World
results.summary_short: ‘The Little Bedroom,’ in French, takes a close look at two human beings sharing their grief while one takes care of the other.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Little Bedroom

results.headline: Underground Folk, Foraging for a Home
results.summary_short: The stop-motion animation studio Laika (“Coraline,” “ParaNorman”) adapts a children’s book by Alan Snow.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Boxtrolls

results.headline: You Can Make It Here, You Can Make It Anywhere
results.summary_short: The documentary “Print the Legend” follows tech-savvy entrepreneurs in the world of 3-D printers.

results.headline: But Hacking Credit Cards Seemed Like Such a Good Idea
results.summary_short: In “Plastic,” young credit card hackers cross a gangster who wants to be paid off.

results.headline: A Stubborn Mother and Her Supplicant
results.summary_short: “Lilting” centers on a young man’s attempts to communicate with a Cambodian-Chinese woman whose son, who recently died, was his lover.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lilting

results.headline: One Small-Timer Finds His Posse
results.summary_short: In “Hellaware,” Keith Poulson is a poseur photographer who makes a poseur band his muse.

results.display_title: JIMI: All Is By My Side
results.headline: The Year When the Guitar Licks Ignited
results.summary_short: “Jimi: All Is by My Side,” a biopic about the musician Jimi Hendrix, is set in 1966, when his popularity was on the verge of exploding.

results.headline: A Brother’s Betrayal, in Darkly Comic Tones
results.summary_short: “It Was You Charlie,” written and directed by Emmanuel Shirinian, focuses on a man whose dream woman is wooed by his brother.

results.headline: Heroically Handy With a Corkscrew
results.summary_short: “The Equalizer” stars Denzel Washington as a seemingly bookish man who turns out to be an assassin on behalf of the wronged.

results.headline: A Chekhovian Bird of a Different Feather
results.summary_short: Christian Camargo’s “Days and Nights” is a modern reworking of Chekhov’s “The Seagull.”

results.headline: No Job, No Money and Now, No Wife
results.summary_short: “Gone Girl,” David Fincher’s movie adaptation of Gillian Flynn’s best seller, focuses on a young wife who goes missing.

results.headline: What Becomes a Woman Most?
results.summary_short: For Ari Seth Cohen, older women, their individuality on parade, have become an obsession and the subject of photographs, a blog and now a documentary.
